step_data.goal: Find and explore communities on OpenStreetMap

	[97] heading 'Communities'
	[100] paragraph ''
		StaticText 'People from all over the world contribute to or use OpenStreetMap. While many participate as individuals, others have formed communities. These groups come in a range of sizes and represent geographies from small towns to large multi-country regions. They can also be formal or informal.'
	[101] heading 'Local Chapters'
	[102] paragraph ''
		StaticText "Local Chapters are country-level or region-level groups that have taken the formal step of establishing not-for-profit legal entities. They represent the area's map and mappers when dealing with local government, business, and media. They have also formed an affiliation with the OpenStreetMap Foundation (OSMF), giving them a link to the legal and copyright governing body."
	[103] paragraph ''
		StaticText 'The following communities are formally established as Local Chapters:'
	[104] list ''
		[105] listitem ''
			ListMarker '•'

	[141] heading 'Other Groups'
	[142] paragraph ''
		StaticText 'There is no need to formally establish a group to the same extent as the Local Chapters. Indeed many groups exist very sucessfully as an informal gathering of people or as a community group. Anyone can set up or join these. Read more on the'
		[143] link 'Communities wiki page', url='https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/User_group'
		StaticText '.'
step_data.thought: I'm currently on the Communities page of OpenStreetMap, which was my goal. The page displays information about different types of OpenStreetMap communities. I can see that the page is organized into sections including 'Local Chapters' which are formally established groups, and 'Other Groups' which are more informal communities. The page lists many local chapter communities from different countries with links to their websites. I should inform the user about what I've found and the different types of communities that exist on OpenStreetMap.
step_data.action: stop('I've found the OpenStreetMap Communities page. There are two main types of communities: 1) Local Chapters - formally established country or region-level groups that have legal entities and are affiliated with the OpenStreetMap Foundation. Examples include OpenStreetMap Belgium, France, US, and many others. 2) Other Groups - informal gatherings or community groups that don't require formal establishment. You can explore any specific community by clicking on their links, or learn more about community groups on the Communities wiki page.')
